t: Isaiah 37
Isaiah Assures Deliverance
And*p so it was, when King Hezekiah heard it,*i that he tore his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth, and went into the house of the Lord.*s
Then he sent Eliakim, who was*i over the household, Shebna the scribe, and the elders of the priests, covered with sackcloth, to Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz.
And they said to him, “Thus says Hezekiah: ‘This day is*i a day of trouble and rebuke and blasphemy; for the children have come to birth, but there*i is*i no strength to bring them forth.

It may be that the Lord*s your God will hear the words of the*i Rabshakeh, whom his master the king of Assyria has sent to reproach the living God, and will rebuke the words which the Lord*s your God has heard. Therefore lift up your*i prayer for the remnant that is left.’”
So*p the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah.

And Isaiah said to them, “Thus you shall say to your master, ‘Thus says the Lord:*s “Do not be afraid of the words which you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed Me.
Surely I will send a spirit upon him, and he shall hear a rumor and return to his own land; and I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land.”’”
Sennacherib’s Threat and Hezekiah’s Prayer
Then*p the*i Rabshakeh returned, and found the king of Assyria warring against Libnah, for he heard that he had departed from Lachish.
And the king heard concerning Tirhakah king of Ethiopia, “He has come out to make war with you.” So when he heard it,*i he sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying,
“Thus you shall speak to Hezekiah king of Judah, saying: ‘Do not let your God in whom you trust deceive you, saying, “Jerusalem shall not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.”
Look! You have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all lands by utterly destroying them; and shall you be delivered?
Have the gods of the nations delivered those whom my fathers have destroyed, Gozan and Haran and Rezeph, and the people of Eden who were*i in Telassar?
Where is*i the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, and the king of the city of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivah?’”
And*p Hezekiah received the letter from the hand of the messengers, and read it; and Hezekiah went up to the house of the Lord,*s and spread it before the Lord.*s
Then Hezekiah prayed to the Lord,*s saying:
“O Lord*s of hosts, God of Israel, the*i One*i who dwells between*i the cherubim, You are*i God, You alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth. You have made heaven and earth.
Incline Your ear, O Lord,*s and hear; open Your eyes, O Lord,*s and see; and hear all the words of Sennacherib, which he has sent to reproach the living God.
Truly, Lord,*s the kings of Assyria have laid waste all the nations and their lands,
and have cast their gods into the fire; for they were*i not gods, but the work of men’s hands—wood and stone. Therefore they destroyed them.
Now therefore, O Lord*s our God, save us from his hand, that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that You are*i the Lord,*s You alone.”
The Word of the Lord Concerning Sennacherib
Then*p Isaiah the son of Amoz sent to Hezekiah, saying, “Thus says the Lord*s God of Israel, ‘Because you have prayed to Me against Sennacherib king of Assyria,

this is*i the word which the Lord*s has spoken concerning him: “The*pn virgin, the daughter of Zion, Has*ld despised you, laughed you to scorn; The*ld daughter of Jerusalem Has*ld shaken her*i head behind your back!
“Whom*ln have you reproached and blasphemed? Against*ld whom have you raised your*i voice, And*ld lifted up your eyes on high? Against*ld the Holy One of Israel.

By*ld your servants you have reproached the Lord, And*ld said, ‘By the multitude of my chariots I*ld have come up to the height of the mountains, To*ld the limits of Lebanon; I*ld will cut down its tall cedars And*ild its choice cypress trees; I*ld will enter its farthest height, To*ld its fruitful forest.
I*ld have dug and drunk water, And*ld with the soles of my feet I have dried up All*ld the brooks of defense.’

“Did*ld you not hear long ago How*ild I made it, From*ld ancient times that I formed it? Now*ld I have brought it to pass, That*ld you should be For*ld crushing fortified cities into*i heaps of ruins.

Therefore*ld their inhabitants had*i little power; They*ld were dismayed and confounded; They*ld were as*i the grass of the field And*ld the green herb, As*ild the grass on the housetops And*ld grain*i blighted before it is grown.
“But*ln I know your dwelling place, Your*ld going out and your coming in, And*ld your rage against Me.

Because*ld your rage against Me and your tumult Have*ld come up to My ears, Therefore*ld I will put My hook in your nose And*ld My bridle in your lips, And*ld I will turn you back By*ld the way which you came.”’

“This*p shall*i be*i a sign to you: You*pn shall eat this year such as grows of itself, And*ld the second year what springs from the same; Also*ld in the third year sow and reap, Plant*ld vineyards and eat the fruit of them.
And*ld the remnant who have escaped of the house of Judah Shall*ld again take root downward, And*ld bear fruit upward.
For*ld out of Jerusalem shall go a remnant, And*ld those who escape from Mount Zion. The*ld zeal of the Lord*s of hosts will do this.

“Therefore*p thus says the Lord*s concerning the king of Assyria: ‘He*pn shall not come into this city, Nor*ld shoot an arrow there, Nor*ld come before it with shield, Nor*ld build a siege mound against it.
By*ld the way that he came, By*ld the same shall he return; And*ld he shall not come into this city,’ Says*ld the Lord.*s
‘For*ld I will defend this city, to save it For*ld My own sake and for My servant David’s sake.’”
Sennacherib’s Defeat and Death
Then*p the angel of the Lord*s went out, and killed in the camp of the Assyrians one hundred and eighty-five thousand; and when people*i arose early in the morning, there were the corpses—all dead.
So Sennacherib king of Assyria departed and went away, returned home,*i and remained at Nineveh.

Now it came to pass, as he was worshiping in the house of Nisroch his god, that his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer struck him down with the sword; and they escaped into the land of Ararat. Then Esarhaddon his son reigned in his place.
